case_vignette:
A man, aged 68 years, with no known history of atopy presents with a 4-month history of an itchy and burning rash on the legs that has been recurring every winter for the past 3 years. He notes that he had dry skin at baseline and did not use emollients, but he did try hydrocortisone 1% cream without improvement. Examination revealed ovoid, erythematous, well-marginated plaques on the lower legs and dorsal feet with variable scaling and focal weeping and crusting. There were no nail changes, and the rest of his skin examination was notable only for xerosis. The patient was diagnosed with chronic winter eczema, and a trial of topical pimecrolimus 1% cream was initiated.

question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have an itchy and burning rash on my legs that recurs every winter.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been experiencing these symptoms for the past 4 months.
Do the rashes improve when the weather becomes warmer?
Yes, the rash has been recurring every winter for the past 3 years.
Do you notice any scaling or flaking along with the rash?
Yes, there is variable scaling on the rash.
Have you been diagnosed with any other skin conditions in the past or are you currently taking any medications?
No, I have no known history of other skin conditions (atopy) and I have tried using hydrocortisone 1% cream without improvement.
Do you have a family history of similar skin issues or other skin diseases?
No, I have no known history of atopy or similar skin issues in my family.
Final Diagnosis: Winter Psoriasis
